effect of light path by gravitational forces

Gravity affects light by curving its path.  This is because gravity affects anything that carries energy, and light, while massless, carries energy.

Light paths are curved by gravity.

Gravitational lensing causes light from a distant star to bend as it passes a massive object.  This can result in the observation of an Einstein ring (a ring of light) or, if the objects aren't perfectly spherical, multiple images of the star.

Gravity, which is a manifestation of spacetime curvature, bends the path of light.  In regions of strong gravitational forces, light does not travel in straight lines but follows curved paths.

Gravity slows down clocks;  this effect, known as time dilation, impacts all clocks, including biological ones.  A twin traveling to a region of strong gravity would return younger than their twin remaining in a region of weaker gravity.  This is separate from time dilation caused by the clocks' motion.

Yes, gravity's effect on time, known as time dilation, does impact clock speed.  Clocks slow down in the presence of gravitational forces.

Gravitational forces cause clocks to slow down.  A clock in a gravitational field will run slower than an identical clock far from such influences. This effect is a consequence of the fact that time itself is affected by gravity.
